Have only really explored the BC scene as I live here, what are your highlights from the other provinces?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18748475
Trans Canada Brewing in Winnipeg
Rebellion Brewing in Regina
Haven't been to any breweries in Ontario that really blew me away but most of them are alright. Best I've been to was probably Tooth and Nail Brewing in Ottawa. The waitress also wasn't wearing a bra and there was a nice bakery across the road.
In Quebec, Frontibus and Naufrager in Gaspesie both make some great beers. Fin du Monde also comes in tallboys in Quebec and you can buy them for 4$ at grocery stores. Probably my favourite beer province not so much for going to breweries but almost all the beer is good and you can buy it anywhere.
Only been to one brewery in New Brunswick, Four Rivers in Bathurst. It was okay but nothing special, which is kind of the impression I've gotten of most NB beers.
Only been to PEI Brewing on PEI. Nothing special.
In Nova Scotia, the best brewery I went to was 2 Crows in Halifax, but I think most of the beer I had from Halifax breweries was pretty good. Schoolhouse Brewery in Windsor was pretty good too.
All the breweries I've visited in Alberta have been kind of eh, but I'm sure there's a good one out there. I had a rye beer from Medicine Hat Brewing which was alright.
In the Yukon, Winterlong is probably the most consistently good but Woodcutters Blanket has made some okay beers and Polarity does some good ones too. Yukon Brewing has been on a downward trend in quality the last three years.
Haven't had any beer from NWT, Nunavut or Newfoundland.
Another of my favourite breweries in BC is Backroads Brewing in Nelson. Also like Category 12 in Saanichton and Driftwood in Victoria (pic related is one of my all time favourite beers).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18748475
>>18748507
Pile'O'Bones (SK), Unibroue (QC), Fuggles & Warlock (BC), and Grizzly Paw (AB) are my favorite Canadian breweries.

I'm pretty much only familiar with SK/AB/BC/YT beer as I've lived in all four locations for a time. I find Rebellion mediocre for SK breweries. Pile'O'Bones, Nokomis, 9 Mile, Malty National, and Bushwakker are all better. I think I have tried every brewery in SK, and those are the best ones and they are very good. For a fairly small province SK has remarkably good food and drink.

YT is small enough that I tried everything and nothing was memorable.

AB I haven't delved into that hard. Everything from Calgary was bad. Grizzly Paw from Canmore is very good, especially on tap. Jasper Brewing I have only had on tap and it was consistently good, but nothing stellar.

The BC beer scene is far more diverse than SK but overwhelmingly disappointing. I've had Dageraad, Strange Fellows, Tailout, Phillips, Hoyne, Lighthouse, Townsite, Persephone, Whistler Brewing, Fuggles & Warlock, Torchlight, Nelson Brewing, Granville Island, Over Time, Grist & Mash, Fernie Brewing, Arrowhead, Whitetooth, Mt. Begbie, Field House, and a bunch of others that I can't even remember. Most of these I have had beer on tap at the breweries themselves.

Fuggles&Warlock and Dageraad are best overall BC breweries.
Field House has one standout blackberry/blueberry sour.
Fernie Brewing has one standout seasonal pumpkin ale.
Whistler has one standout seasonal winter dunkel (sweet orange&spice dessert beer).
Granville Island has a night light summer raspberry ale.
The rest are forgettable and can't even do a good basic brown, amber, etc.

>>18763936
tater tot "hotdish" (casserole).

it's basically browned ground beef mixed with cream of mushroom soup, corn (optional), green beans (optional), put into a casserole dish with a layer of cheese and tater tots on top. basically it's something you could make when you live somewhere cold and remote where it's winter most of the year, and the only things you can get fresh are beef and dairy. a cuisine based around canned or frozen goods.

it's better than it looks if the tater tots and beef are good. I prefer it without the corn and green beans, though I like vegetables, because the canned veggie flavor permeates the dish. natives prefer it that way apparently.

checked. I think the word "hotdish" is just a midwestern thing, and only Minnesota and North Dakota afaik. but hotdish/casserole culture definitely seems to be a bigger deal here than anywhere else I've lived. it seems like the culture around it goes back to WWI and depression era times of scarcity, when canned foods were novel and popular, and of course because it's cheap and easy to make for potlucks and gatherings (e.g. for church). I'm not from this region originally but it's all interesting to me, and a good casserole is pretty nice. certain other regions in the US I've lived in don't seem to have such distinct regional cuisines.

I want to make a casserole now. we just got like a foot of snow last night and the power was out. any comfy recommendations?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18772389
stores well, easy, hardy, filling, and they weren't using their actual fields to grow it, they were growing it in their gardens next to their houses. the fields had grains or fiber crops like flax. they grew all sorts of things until the harvest came in, to fill in the time and keep themselves fed throughout the year. and the things that grew throughout the year varied, because different things grow at different times. the leanest time of year was spring, which is why the lent fast is timed to then. in summer and fall there was basically free food everywhere with minimal effort, and in winter if you were smart you had stores. but in spring the stores were empty and nothing had grown yet, so you fasted. radishes are just about the first thing ready, and they take 25 to 40 days, coincidentally about the length of lent...cabbages come in around 50 days. carrots take about 60 to 80, though you can eat them before that around 40, they're just small baby ones. potatoes have a growing season of like 120 days iirc though I've never grown them.

early american colonists were struggling because they didn't know good timings and were often underprepared. they were trying to use european crops and methods that they knew, but improperly adapted to their new surroundings. the plymouth expeditions, for example, thought they were landing much further south than they actually did. this led to wildly improper plantings. once they were told the timings by the locals they did fine.

my dad tells me stories of his family's farm and they'd have three rows of cabbage in the garden and that'd be enough cabbage they'd be sick of it over winter. my mom, similarly, tells me stories of chinese peasants with literal rooms full of cabbage over winter, because it stored forever. it's good stuff.

They use way less saturated fats, butter amd cream are rare ingredients, which become more common the more you move to the North.
Almost everything that is available in North regions is also available in the South but not the other way around.
Southerns are also masters at making incredibly good recipes that use very few ingredients.
Lemon granita is literally water, lemon and sugar but anyone who has tasted it knows why it's an absolutely top tier dessert.They also have their elaborate dishes that somehow aren't ridiculously fattening. For instance Pasta con le Sarde is surprisingly healthy and incredibly tasty, so is Caponata.

Tl;dr the reasons are
>Mediterranean climate
>multicultural influence throughout history
>alternating periods of extreme richness (Ancient Greece, Roman Empire, Arabs and Normans) with extreme poverty (post RE-fall, Spanish domination) so both rich and poor cuisine were highly developed.

>>18771061
>Southerns are also masters at making incredibly good recipes that use very few ingredients

This can't be understated.
Modica's chocolate is the closest thing we have to ancient Aztec chocolate today.
It's cocoa seeds + sugar (+ sometimes chili pepper like the original Aztec chocolate), no added cocoa butter and entirely cold processed. The ratio is usually 70% cocoa and 30% sugar.
It's tastes just as good as regular chocolate and has a unique grainy consistency that is very pleasant.

>>18771223
I work in one - keep in mind that I don't work in the messhall nor even work with the inmates.
There's stuff like chili, stuff is all cheap obviously. I'm pretty sure there's a lot of carbs, I /think/ at worst a decent amount of cheap protein. Some guys get kosher food (which I hear gets them more cheese which, isn't often given out), some are on a cold-only diet (whatever that's intended for). Some guys pretend they're Jewish (and Muslim maybe) to get more holiday meals. Special holiday food can include meat not cooked from frozen (one had meat cooked from a bag, I've seen a religious event where they got freshly-cooked chicken), and they sometimes can get one of those little ice cream cups (with the wooden spoon) as a special treat on some of those days. I saw that cheap canned vegetable mix spilled outside a building today with some pieces of bread. There's special food for the guys that graduate college while in the joint (sounds like they're going to get cake, chicken wings, and pizza from a local grocery chain.) Where I am i's currently banned for family members to send or being /any/ sort of.food, unless they order it directly from a vendor, so them getting freah food has been harder. When comissary was out of cigs once they were buying Twix bars to bet with. They're also banning, if not have already banned personal can food at my joint. I'm not the best person to ask but that's a rough udea.

posts.com: Haven’t been myself but a buddy did two years for slinging h. It’s a lot of bread, “sandwiches” (baloney & process cheese on white bread), stews, mystery loaf, and generally just heavy stuff that makes you want to take naps and not cause trouble. Almost no seasoning except salt, everything is flavorless. Allegedly they used to offer packets of hot sauce in the canteen but had to stop because inmates would squirt it into the eyes of enemies & guards. Anything sweet like brownies & cinnamon rolls was in high demand, you could buy basically anything with a cinnamon roll like it was cash. No hot beverages or caffeine whatsoever. Everything made to be eaten with just a spoon for obvious reasons. Thanksgiving was the one day of the year they got anything resembling real food, real roasted turkey, stuffing and cranberry sauce but still no seasoning on anything except loads of salt.

>>18771223
Fatima's Grill, a TikTok zoomer meme restaurant in LA, server recipes based on the owner's prison time:

>[The owner], who previously had no significant cooking experience, conceived of the restaurant and many of his recipes while working in the kitchen at the Federal Correctional Institution, Safford in Arizona, where he was serving a 7.5-year sentence for drug trafficking. After opening the restaurant, [he] at one point had to return to Safford to list his ingredients, as he sourced many of the items he uses in his dishes from the prison commissary.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fatima%27s_Grill

As you see in pic related, notable ingredients include Flamin' Hot Cheetos, and also a special sauce that gets shipped all the way from the famous Capitol State Penitentiary cafeteria in New Britain, CT. The cafeteria is known to inmates as “Crapitol Lunch” and are known to come in and ask for “the shit sauce”. 2 hotdogs and an order of fries is commonly called a “Big Shitter”. You won’t find this on any menu, but if you’re a true prison lifer you’ll know. The Famous Sauce is often served in small ramekins commonly called “dookie drops” by inmates and used for dipping. The sauce is also sold as contraband, 10 cigarettes for an 8 ounce container, something many Aryan Brotherhood gang members take advantage of due to the popularity of the Famous Sauce. Inmates know to order it as a “Big Dump” and the cafeteria workers aren’t shy about giving a little extra to prisoners who order this way, knowing they’re what’s called a “murder city madman” and thus one of their own.

"Land use" - ranchland is usually in an otherwise empty, useless area. If we were kicking people out of their houses to build cowscrapers this complaint would make any sense.
"Water use" - This is often meaningless. A California almond grower is using a precious resource. A cow in the Mississippi basin is using a worthless one.
"Emissions" - methane decays quickly. The environmentalists are asking us to go off meat and dairy for the rest of time for a one-time savings of a few years of one of subset of emissions.

>>It's expensive right now
>Cost would go down
There's already more than enough demand and production for economies of scale to kick in for plant milk. Costs would in fact only go up as inputs like almonds were hit with more demand.
The fact that cow milk is cheaper is a tiny little hint being whispered in your ear by the market that this infographic is a lie, and processing plant milk is actually more resource-intensive in some ways than milking cows.

I live in an apartment and had my broken oven replaced but when I heat it up it smells chemically and the food I tried to cook has a gross aftertaste. I did some googling, does this shit work bros?

Good ol’ boiling water and vinegar will do the trick

This may come as a surprise to you, but boiling water can also do the trick of absorbing bad odours from the oven. Pour a litre of water into a baking dish and add 1 cup of vinegar to the mixture.

Preheat the oven to 200°C and place the dish on the lowest rack. Leave the water to boil in the oven for around an hour. Water will evaporate and absorb the smells in the process. Vinegar will also help with absorbing the potent smells and will leave the oven odour-free.

I am doing it right now and can smell the vinegar instead of the gross chemical shit so I guess that is a start. Any other tips I should know so I can stop having to go to my parents just to cook?

It's cheap, doesn't taste terrible, but quite unhealthy. Bongs have a lot of cultural / nostalgic attachment to it, but your average local baker will be far superior. One of the things the brits to extremely well is meat wrapped in pastry.
greggs and other similar stores offer quick and hot pastry filled with all kinds of filling like steak, chicken and mushroom, cheese and onion.
Sausage rolls are a staple.
The also do breakfast sandwiches and soup.

Basically hot comfort food to deal with the cold and the shit weather.

Greggs is a little too salty and greasy for me

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18766003
There are cloth and metal filters that are not disposable if you want to try that.
Personally I'd suggest cowboy coffee because you only need a pot and no other equipment.
My method:
>Boil water until it bubbles
>turn stove off and drop your grounds
>let them rest for 4 minutes
>Stir
>let them est for 6 minutes
>sprinkle some cold water from the tap so the grounds sink to the bottom
>serve straight from the pot to the cup
Very simple and very flavorful, any other method will filter out something but cowboy coffee is the most complete, it's only downside is that it's slow.
Moka pots, espresso machine and french presses also do not use anything disposable

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Picopresso anon here. I think I've dialed in as good an espresso as I'm going to get from a handleld, unpowered machine I got for less than $150. What I got was a very nice espresso. I've certainly had better espressos, but then again, I've often had much worse espressos at specialty coffee shops working with several thousand dollars worth of equipment. Obviously the next step is to try a better bean, and luckily, there's no shortage of specialty roasters around me. I think at this point, though, the hurdle is going to be brew temperature, which is just an inherent flaw not just with this machine, but with any manual machine that isn't powered. In fact, I feel like temperature would be an issue even with a more expensive manual machine like a Flair, simply because they tend to be made of machined aluminum, and I already know from being a PC gamer, that aluminum is a fantastic heatsink material, which makes it a terrible material for a water chamber that needs to remain at a certain temp.

So now comes the big, obvious question: can I get a decent espresso machine for under $300, ideally one with a PID, or at the very least, one that self heats the water chamber? Either a manual/piston/lever powered one, or an electric one. I've tried doing a search for "budget espresso machines," but they recommend things with pressurized baskets, like those cheap Mr. Coffee machines, and I want one that I can really dial in and make a real, proper espresso.

Gaggia Classic Pro has its many fans but you have to fuck with it and mod it (at significant cost) before you have all the features redditors obsess over, like PID. >>18767014
Sounds like you're buying shit coffee.

How to Brew
Suggested ratio: 60–70g/litre
Grind size: Medium to medium-fine
Buying advice: The iconic cafetière is glass, and most of the presses available are glass bodied. However, for a couple of reasons I’d recommend stretching to a dual-walled, stainless-steel version if your budget allows. Primarily, I recommend these because they’re unbreakable and glass most definitely is not. More expensive glass options generally have better and stronger glass, but a stainless-steel version will last a lifetime. Secondly, for those with a concern about the loss in temperature with a longer brew time, like the one I recommend, a dual-walled, stainless-steel press will retain the heat much better than glass.

Some people do say they can taste something ‘off’ or metallic with stainless-steel brewers, but in blind testing I’ve never been able to detect any difference. However, it is possible some people have a particular sensitivity that I do not.

Maintenance: Soap and water should be used after every brew. If for any reason you start to get a brown patina building up on the brewer, then dissolve about 1 tablespoon (10g) of espresso-machine cleaner (I use Cafiza, but other brands also work well) per litre of very hot water and soak for a few hours before rinsing thoroughly.

That's another thing to note when seeing people bitch in reviews. Some people have shitty water. Some people don't clean their shit. Its not just oxo, thats just how it works. >>18771453
>diameter affects flavor, since you're changing the dynamics
Diameter, hole placement, basket taper, and dose(puck height for a given diameter) will all affect change the resistance of your puck, which will affect pressure/flow, which will affect taste.

Has anyone in this board grown culinary mushrooms for eating? This is food but I've never seen a thread about it. Let me introduce you guys to the fun of growing mushrooms. It's so easy and this hobby can provide hours of active entertainment.

To start with, I had the idea to try growing oyster mushrooms that I got from the grocery store. These cost about $15/lb here which is quite a scam considering they can be cloned by an average retard. So check this out, all you have to do is take out little bits from the mushrooms with a scalpel and feed them. Then they'll grow into a new organism. I will give more details in subsequent posts.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18768748
So what you're seeing in these images is little bits of flesh that I extracted from inside the fleshiest part of the mushroom. The secret that Big Mushroom doesn't want you to know is that you have to do all this in an extremely clean environment. Mushrooms are a fungus, and so is mold, which means that in order to grow mushrooms you need to essentially prepare a perfect environment for mold to grow, but without growing mold. The only way to do this is by physically preventing a single mold spore to come in. So when you open up the mushrooms, do so by ripping them, and then use a flame -sterilized scalpel to carefully get out a piece of flesh. All of this needs to be done inside a still air box, which can be made by overturning a large plastic tote and cutting two armholes so you can do mushroom stuff inside it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18768775
The medium that I have placed the flesh on is malt extract agar. This is essentially a nutrient-rich jelly which is used to fill petri dishes, which is normally used to cultivate funguses and bacteria in a lab environment. I am using small plastic ketchup containers instead of real petri dishes because I'm poor. In order to make these things, you need a few powder ingredients (the nutrients and the agar) and then you mix it with water and pressure cook it for 45 minutes to make sure there isn't a single living organism or spore in the mixture. Then pour it into ketchup containers (inside the still air box) while it's still hot, and let it cool, and it becomes a nutritious and delicious and sterile medium on which you can propagate mushroom clones.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18768809
In the last couple images, and this one, you can see how the mushroom flesh sends out fibers to colonize and eat the agar jelly. It's so beautiful to watch this. The purpose of the jelly step is to make sure that our cultures do not have any contaminants in them. Like I was saying before, this entire game is basically about getting a clean culture which doesn't have any bacteria or mold. The original mushrooms were in the grocery store for God knows how long, getting sneezed on and poked by gross children and bugs, and are covered in contamination. I lost three of five of the original agar cups to bacteria. But you can clone the fuzz from these cups by cutting out a clean and healthy piece and transferring it to a fresh cup. And basically, you can keep doing this indefinitely to make as much as you want, until your cultures are 100% clean.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18768834
Quick background on mushroom biology: mushrooms aren't plants. They are more closely related to humans than they are to plants. Basically, the entire organism is a big fluffy network called the mycelium, which in the wild, lives normally underground or inside trees. And it eats food like animals. The mushroom itself, which you eat, is basically just a sex organ of the mycelium. It sprouts forth from the soil or out the side of a tree to release spores in very certain conditions. But 99% of the organism is this white fluff which is hidden from view.

So what you can do is provoke a bit of a mushroom to grow more of this fluff, which I've just shown you how to do. Then you can feed it until it becomes big, which I'm going to show you how to do next.

Mycelium loves to eat whole grains, so after you have got some clean cuttings isolated on agar, then you're gonna want to multiply it faster by feeding it some grains. Popular and cheap choices include wild birdseed, whole oats, popcorn kernels, and brown rice.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18768876
What you do to make the jars is: soak your grains of choice in water overnight until they're nice and saturated. Then strain, then dump them out onto a few baking sheets and let them dry off until they're dry on the outside. You want the grains to be fully wet on the inside (full of water) but not actually be wet on the outside, so they're just at maximum internal water capacity. That's the perfect hydration level. Then put the grains inside some jars and pressure cook them at 15psi for 90 minutes to kill all the mold and bacteria inside the jars. Then you will have some jars of mushroom food which your mycelium will love to eat.

After the jars are cool, bring them into your still air box and put the mycelium from the jelly cups inside. Cut the jelly into little squares with a flame-sterilized scalpel before you dump them in. Then give it a good shake so the mycelium gets spread around in the grains. This will help it colonize faster.

This is what my jars looked like after a day of the mycelium spreading around the grains.

Well, maybe these pictures are from after a few days. But the stuff grows really fast.

Once you're at the grainjar stage, assuming you were really careful not to introduce any bacteria or mold into your jars, then you should basically be cooking with fire. The grain spawn generates mycelium at an incredibly fast rate. You can use a flame-sterilized spoon to scoop some colonized grains out of one jar, into a second jar, shake the thing up, and it'll be fully colonized in another week. Keep doing this to have infinite mycelium forever.

The final stage is that the colonized grain spawn will be used to incubate these giant bags, which contain a mixture of 50% hickory sawdust and 50% soy hulls. These ingredients are chosen to replicate the environment of a dead tree, which is where oyster mushrooms actually grow. This step is used to basically stretch your dollar further. You could fruit mushrooms right out of a grain jar, but for a few cents extra you can colonize an entire 6lb block of sawdust and get more mushrooms than you know what to do with. Each jar can colonize like 12 of these bags.

If you guys are interested in this hobby, don't fall for the "kits". You can buy "mushroom grow kits" on the internet which basically come with a small pre-sterilized bag of substrate, and a syringe of liquid mycelium culture for you to inject in there. These things are basically a fun toy or an interesting gift for someone in the office, but they're not close to efficient compared to doing everything yourself. I can make these large 5lb fruiting blocks for about $1.50 each, which will be largely converted into mushroom, whereas the grow kits are basically more expensive than just buying mushrooms at the store. And doing all this stuff is way more fun anyway.

posts.com:
>>18769096
Just reread my own ramblings and I could've elaborate more on the final step. When you're making your fruiting blocks, the best source for sawdust is hardwood pellets used for pellet grills and smokers. You can buy hickory pellets at Lowes for 37 cents a pound. Soy hulls are an agricultural waste product and you can buy it online for even cheaper than that. I think they're normally used to feed pigs. The best recipe for bulk substrate for woodloving mushrooms, which includes oysters and shiitake, is 1 part sawdust, 1 part soy hulls, and 3 parts water, all by weight.

There are some alternative substrates which you can use to varying degrees of success. Oysters can also be grown on a mixture of straw and coffee grounds. Or just sawdust, or just straw.

You also don't need to use these bags, obviously, you can use any container. But these are cheap, large, and transparent. And they're safe to pressure cook, which you'll need to do depending on how nutritious your substrate is. If you're just using pure straw, you can just soak it in water and put it right in the bags, and then dump the grain spawn on top and shake it up. Mushroom mycelium has its own immune system, as it's a complex living organism after all, so it's naturally pretty resistant to mold and bacteria once it's established. You can expose a fully colonized jar to the open air, or dump it in a bag of straw, and it will be fine. But soy hulls and coffee grounds are extremely nutritional and encourage the growth of competitive mold. So with these more effective substrates, you need to pressure cook them just like you did the grain jars.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18769113
There's outdoor cultivation methods which mimic the natural environment much more closely. If you grow mushrooms outside it's pretty similar to composting and you don't need to sterilize anything. However, whether you can do this depends largely on your local climate and what you want to grow. And it's also pretty much a crapshoot and less controlled than what I'm doing here. Like you can get some mushrooms from the grocery store and shred them up, throw them on the ground in your backyard, and cover it with a pile of hardwood chips and sawdust and coffee grounds, and your weather and local humidity is right, then mushrooms are probably gonna grow out of it. But it might be multiple years before you see anything and you won't have huge yield, and you might accidentally grow some other shit you didn't want. Most people in this hobby throw their spent substrate in a pile in the backyard and extra mushrooms keep randomly growing out for many years. But that's only worth it because you might as well do it, I wouldn't rely on that as a reliable farming method.

Another cool thing you can do is to inoculate an entire log with spores or liquid culture from a log colonizing species. I have seen it done where someone gets a whole log, then drills a few holes in it and inseminates the log with mycelium, then plugs the holes and wait for mushrooms to start popping out of the log. On Paul Stamets website he sells mushroom plugs that you can stick right into a log for this purpose. However I've never done this so I can't speak in depth about it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18770131
I paid $78 for my pressure canner from Walmart, but I actually had it from before I started growing mushrooms because I used it to actually can stuff. You can also pressure cook a whole turkey in there which comes out really tender and fast. Honestly it's a neat contraption that's kinda worth having just in general. And that's really the only major expense.

Other than that I have bought a large plastic tub to use as a still air box, 18 glass jars and 24 big bags, 40lbs of birdseed, agar powder on Amazon, soy hulls and wood pellets. I would estimate probably about $60-80 total for all this stuff, and I still have a lot of consumable material left over. I think my first crop will come out cheaper per lb than the mushrooms I originally bought at the store to clone. Eventually I could produce them for about $1.70 per lb in the best case.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I finally quit after 12 years of nicotine use and I feel completely fine. It was only hell for about a week, and then there were 2 more weeks of constantly thinking about nicotine and having to be sad that I couldn't have anymore. But now it's been a month and I'm completely over it, no more withdrawal symptoms, no more cravings, just feel 100% fine and normal. Except I don't need to keep consuming nicotine in order to be comfortable. I basically can just be comfortable indefinitely. It feels like there's a magical nicotine patch inserted inside my skin and it never runs out, so it just keeps feeding me pleasure and keeping me feeling content. I had no idea I could be like this. It's really awesome.

I always thought that if I quit, my life would basically be hell forever, since I'd always have to keep missing nicotine every day for the rest of my life. I thought it would be like having a wife tragically killed in a car accident and then you always miss her forever. I thought that even though the physical withdrawal could obviously go away, and chemically my brain would go back to normal, I'd never be able to forget the knowledge of how much I love smoking and dipping. I thought since I ate the forbidden fruit of knowledge, I was doomed to nicotine slavery forever.

I just can't express to you guys how fucking crazy it is that the feeling of missing cigarettes and feeling down and "lonely" about quitting, it literally just went away in under a month. I can't believe it was that fucking easy all along, and I just never stuck it out long enough to find this out sooner. I have been an addict for 12 fucking years and wishing I could stop for most of that time. And all along I literally could.

>>18747625
Nicaraguan cigars are as good or better than Cuban cigars and have been for a while.
When Castro took over, some tobacco growers took their best seeds and traveled around Latin America looking for the ideal location to replant: Nicaragua. Nicaraguan cigars aren’t as prestigious as Cubans, but they’re as good or better for a fraction of the cost, not to mention that it’s very hard to get Cubans in some countries.
Fun fact: A few years ago, Cuban tobacco was devastated by a hurricane, so the producers went abroad in search of the best seed: Nicaragua. So, the Cubans you’re smoking today were likely grown from Nicaraguan seed.

If they are totally dry you must be very careful. If you just put them into a humid environment they will swell and split.

If I were doing it again I would try to add like 3 rH per week for 7 weeks.

Pro tip to any anons here wanting to break free from wagie life with as little work as possible.
Scrape up 4700 dollars, not necessary but it makes life easier
Get a CDL-A
Get an Over the Road trucking job and live in your truck for about 5 years. Get your food stuffs from Walmart, you can always get a truck into Walmart. Get a cooker made for truckers. Buy water/drink of choice too
You CAN get internet on the road to shitpost/play vidya. Just spend a lil on a phone plan that gives you a mobile hotspot for a laptop, you're set.
Driving a truck pays fat cash, especially when you don't have to pay rent or a mortgage or send money home to a family. The driving part is best described like this: hours of boredom and seconds of terror. Just drive safe and stay alert and you will be alright.
If you cant get 4700 just find a company that will pay for your CDL training. They will force you to work for them for 6 months in exchange but you will still get paid, just not as much as a good company will. The more experience you get the more pay you can get.
DO. NOT. SIGN. A. LEASE.
Save your Loves/Flying J/Pilot fuel points to get free showers/drinks. Dont go to TA if you can help it.
If you have a gf/wife then dont do this. If you have kids, dont do this. This is for single guys with nothing but free time who want their fat stacks but have no real drive or ambition or talent.
If it works for me, it can work for anyone.
Disclaimer: i am not a boomer who did this 20 years ago. I did it two years ago. Its not paradise by a wide shot. But it is FAR better than ANY faggot retail job I ever had, EVER.

>>18759459
The average payout here looks to be about $1/km. If you really know how to play the system here, you can legally drive for 12.5h every 24h for 6 days a week. If it's just long-haul, full load to the destination at the end of that week, loaded and unloaded on your day off, you're still looking at a 70h cap (we have the option of 120h over a 14 day period, but it doesn't usually help). You're looking at an average speed of 75km/h, so... quickmath... It's possible to make about $5500 per week or $275k/a in Ontario, Canada, as a maximum. The average, working full tilt is probably more like $3000/wk / 150k/a because of deliveries, maintenance, construction, etc.

I thought about doing that, but then I found that logistics in the film industry can pay almost as well, and depending on what the day entails (if I have to remain on set), I can make $600/day (my absolute minimum is $300, usually low end is $450) to drop a truck and trailer off maybe an hour away, somewhere that a team of locations personnel has cleared and coned off for me. I've got all day to do maintenance, or a few more leisurely timed drops and pickups if I'm leaving set. If I wind up having to help the audio or video guys, I can charge an assistant fee on top (an extra $350)... and because I'm on time and useful, I've got a bunch of these guys scheming with me. If all goes well in the next year, I'll have a small fleet of all-in-one-ish trailers and some client-oriented video busses at my disposal, a dedicated vehicle return and maintenance crew, and I'll have to actually work for 13h a day, but I'll be pulling in $1500-ish a day 5 or 6 days a week, possibly with paid holidays.

Works at one of the busiest McDonalds in England, London Gatwick Airside.

Not only was it insanely busy with huge long queues but most of the passengers were stressed out, a large portion of which had food vouchers from their flights being delayed. Few people ever went full on rage as having patrolling police officers with semi-auto rifles tends to stop people going too far but most people you'd serve were grumpy.

Also, this conversation happened way too often

>"hi do you accept dollars?"
>"yes but we give an awful exchange rate and the change will be in pounds is that ok?"
>"sure"
>"ok, that meal is £2.99, in dollars that's $6.21"
>*customer hands over a $20 bill"
>"here's £5.12 in change"
>"What? That's way too expensive! And what am I going to do with pounds now?!?"

To make it extra fun there was pretty much impossible to do a refund for these.

The real scientific hangover cure is:

Water, can include electrolyte sachet
Eat a whole raw yellow grapefruit or drink half a litre of no added sugar grapefruit juice slowly(Not pink grapefruit)
A slice of toast with peanut butter
Wait a short while and drink a strong coffee
10mins of exercise

Theory is; Water to rehydrate, Yellow grapefruit contains lots of amino acids that your liver uses to remove alcohol from your bloodstream. Toast has slow burning energy to fuel the process and peanut butter contains lots of Iron that your liver and kidneys need to replenish for optimal function. Once your liver is loaded with amino acids, down a strong coffee to increase bloodflow, exercise to increase your heart rate to cycle the blood through your liver while the Amino acids are working.
US Military used this for a long time as the beginning of their 3day diet for people who got fat during breaks between deployment.

A good trick is to puke before you go to bed to remove any excess booze, I've found that it shortens the duration of the hangover a fair bit.
You can also drink more in the morning but the moment you finish your first or second drink you're on the crash clock and probably don't have more than an hour or two.

The hard truth though is if you're REALLY hungover (10 pints or a bottle of vodka etc) then you're fucked no matter what. You're either too hungover for what you want to do or you're not and there's not a lot you can do in the morning about that.

Wow. I have never seen a more homosexual image in all my life.

Personally I tried hair of the dog but that's just asking for alcoholism. It doesn't actually work.

A classic technique is just taking some headache pills before you start getting a headache (when you feel your head tightening a bit, now is the time). Then drinking water as you go, maybe have a slice of toast before bed, all these together helps prevent a bad hangover in the first place.
If you're drinking heavily, avoid any strong painkillers, it's a bad combo and can leave you struggling to breathe. Best to just skip it in this case. Wake up and force a good breakfast in you, something with lots of carbs works well.
It may feel like shit but nothing is worse than lying in bed with a hangover and just suffering.
I avoid dairy the morning after because my stomach does not thank me after lots of drinking. Stay hydrated, eat something salty and filling before bed and you're practically good to go.

A pan gives you more ability to control the juices, since pan searing tends to be easier and better than grill searing (and searing on a charcoal grill is not really an option if you've waited for the fire to cool down to cooking temperature); however, you don't get smoke flavoring cooking in a pan on your stove. I can definitely understand people who do a hybrid pan sear and then place the steak and pan together over a charcoal fire, to get the best of both worlds.

posts.com:
>>18768046
Best of both worlds - grilled DIRECTLY on the charcoal. No grate, no pan.

If anyone wants to try:
Get the charcoal red hot all over, get the steak up to room temp. When ready, blow strongly on the coal. The reason for this is you don't want the ash on the steak so you blow it off. Then place the steak directly on the charcoal. Don't turn until one side is ready. If the coal goes dark under the steak, move it (don't forget to blow off the ash from the spot where you want to move the steak).
Cook from both sides, use a steak thermometer if you can. From medium rare you want something around 54 degrees celsius (130 fahrenheit).
When turning the steak, remove any coal that stuck to the already cooked side.
What you get is a steak with perfect sear AND the charcoal flavor.
I know this sounds like a bad idea and you might think the steak will burn to shit, but it won't. This is seriously probably the best way to cook a steak.
You're welcome.

The best homemade marshmallow is italian meringue.

Italian meringue is a marshmallow because marshmallow is defined by sugar syrup that has been whipped with protein to a soft but solid consistency. Replace the protein from gelatin with the protein from egg whites and that's still a marshmallow.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18770241
yeah, italian meringue is cooked, not raw. You're supposed to slowly drizzle HOT (245ºF) sugar syrup into your egg whites while whipping. it's dangerous because hot sugar syrup is not only hotter than boiling water but if any of it gets on your skin, it instantly sticks to and burns you, so be very careful.
But the hot sugar syrup being whipped into the egg whites should be enough to cook them. I even give the egg whites a head start by whipping them gently over very very very low heat until they get to be about 90ºF before adding the super hot syrup.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
pastebin anon here again
Im working on revamping the western brewing instructions, these are meant to be for beginners and Im assuming they will at most rebrew one time
If you can test any of these and give feedback or have other comments let me know
For black tea use 1-1.5 grams per 100ml of water, use boiling or freshly boiled water, brew for 3 minutes.
For green tea use 1-2 grams per 100ml of water, use 70c-75c water, brew for 3 minutes
For green oolongs use 1-2 grams per 100ml of water, use 80c water, brew for 3-4 minutes
for dark or roasted oolongs use 1.5-2.5 grams per 100ml of water, use 90c-100c water, brew for 4-5 minutes
for ripe puer or other fermented teas 1.5-2 grams per 100ml of water, use boiling or freshly boiled water, brew for 5-7 minutes
for young green puer strongly consider gongfu brewing instead, 1.5-2 grams per 100ml of water, use 90c water, brew for 2-3 minutes
for yellow tea? 1-1.5 grams per 100ml of water, use 80c water, brew for 2-3 minutes

>>18771546
Great improvement if only for dropping the multiple steeping stuff. 99% of people aren't even aware tea can be steeped more than once, it simply isn't done except by tea nerds fascinated with the Far East. Some places like Turkey or southern US steep tea for 15+ minutes. Directions shouldn't be totally out of touch with real life culture, typical teabag/sachet suggestions, western vendors, and ISO 3103. Here's the current version for reference
https://cdn.standards.iteh.ai/samples/73224/79469b30ce154460b38ebb10af5565cf/ISO-3103-2019.pdf

Example instructions from Upton: 2.25g 6oz (177ml) 3-4 min.
Vahdam: 2g 180ml 3-5 min.

Lipton stringed teabags contain 2.25g of tea and UK square teabags contain 3.125g. PG Tips has 2.9g. ISO 3103 traditionally used 2.83g based on an old sixpence coin. This goes into a 6-10 ounce sized cup, or 140ml for ISO 3103.
Teabag packaging directions are typically 2-5 minutes. ISO 3103 is 6 minutes for black tea with milk, 3-5 minutes for other types depending on how chopped up it is.
Green tea is fine up to 80-85C and others can use off-the-boil or more precisely 86-90C is ideal. This is based on several papers I can link if you're curious, plus I tested with a thermapen. There's not a lot of nuance. Either the tea has catechins damaged by boiling water (green) or it doesn't.

Also, u guise, keep in mind it's often mixed with milk and/or sugar. Astringency is "body" which is desirable to an extent. Upscale stores unironically offer CTC and African tea. A lot of tea is created without any consideration for drinking it like a Chinaman. It's grown in other countries too.

Do a 36 hour fast. After dinner tonight, don't eat until breakfast the day after next. It helps reset your appetite from constant hunger. The goal is not to feel full all the time it's to be able to tolerate going without food.
From then on, don't snack in between meals, and if it's ever time for a meal and you find that you're not hungry, skip the meal. Sounds difficult now but after a fast it gets so much easier.

>>18770208
I used to be 300 lbs and lost almost 150 lbs over the course of 1.5 years. I can promise you this - it's hard as fuck at the start, but if you stick to whatever diet/ exercise routine for just a month, you adapt to the change and it stops being hard. You will very quickly see positive results which will be insanely motivating and will make the transformation that much more satisfying.

In terms of actually making the change - take small steps, don't go cold turkey. I started just by changing how much I ate rather than trying to eat healthy. Instead of 2 burgers at the college cafeteria, i'd have one. Instead of the whole bag of chips I'd have half, that kind of thing. When that became easy I'd make another small change, until eventually, over several months, I'd developed a healthy routine that felt sustainable. If it makes you miserable every day, you're not going to stick to it.

-Go to bed early. The hours before midnight count double.
-Ditch worthless "friends" who keep sucking you into deep fried garbage and staying up late, even the ones who mean well.

-A nutritionist is a doctor specialized in nutrition. Make an appointment at your local hospital as soon as possible.
-A dietician is a fraud, who writes for teenage girl magazines, stay as far away as possible.
-Don't buy prefab food, make your own. Avoid bottled sauces, stock pots ("it's your choice really"), canned, frozen food and factory bread.
-A glass of alcohol a day is good. Keep it at that.
-Carbs are bad, but you need to have some to keep your blood-sugar in check.
-Fibres are great, but bad for your thyroid gland, don't exaggerate with celery: it's close to 0 calories and full of fibre, a healthy snack which satisfies your hunger feeling.
-Be active. Activity burns calories. If you lose more calories than you take in, you'll get better. You don't have to lift weights or go swimming. Start with a 15 minute walk after every meal, that adds up to a 45 minute hike every day. If it's too hot, too cold, or you're just too embarrassed: go up and down a flight of stairs for 5 minutes instead.
-Grow your own produce, even in winter. Radicchio, all cabbage varieties, lamb's lettuce, Belgian endive, most mushrooms, all shoots (herbs, spices, leek, alphalpha, beetroot, radishes, hop...). Simple, honest and tasty DIY alternatives to garbage hot sauces.

>>18771479
>>18771638
It's called a "milk shake" not because the milk is "shaked", but because it's derived from the German "milch schächer" or "milk thieves", which were mischievous, though friendly, elves/gnomes who were said to steal milk from a household and, in order to avoid detection, would replace it with a mixture of cold cream sweetened with honey and spices. The tradition was for parents to make the dessert, late at night, and leave it outside to cool, and bring it inside, in the morning, claiming that the "milch schächen have taken their milk and tried to fool us with this", much to the children's delight. This was, generally, done during the first days of the farming season and signaled the sunny, cheerier times to come (most likely, it has pre-Christian roots; old folklore has similar creatures who used to steal livestock). As industrialization and urbanization took over, obviously, the spring aspect became less important, but the drink remained popular and German immigrant in the States made it, too. While today's milkshakes bear little resemblance to the original recipe, they're still a direct descendant.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Reduced carb bread/pizza dough (percentages are by weight): 40% lupin flour, 40% vital wheat gluten, 20% almond flour. Add water with equal mass to your dry ingredients. Use whatever yeast you want plus a sprinkle of wheat flour, I use sourdough starter. Also add a few tbsp of olive oil and couple teaspoons salt. 500g dry ingredients is pretty good size for a loaf. Give it a good kneading and cook in Dutch oven at 220C for 20 mins lid on, 40 mins lid off or until cooked through.

No, it doesn't look like that. You're probably too dumb to notice the text that says "colors are relative and do not correspond to absolute temperatures."

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I use it, but many people don't understand how to.

A. It's a salt, so if you add it you have to reduce the regular salt, often people double up on salt because there was salt in a sauce they used or somthing.

B. It's a salt, so you add it last. People make the same mistake of adding it into something before they cook it down.

C. It's a salt, so you can easily saturate your palate if you add it to a sauce. You're adding MSG to every individual drop of sauce. Industrially MSG is often used as a powder.

D. Be sure there's no MSG in your food to begin with, it might be listed as E621 and there are several related analogues .
Some food is also MSG rich to begin with like fish sauce, soya sauce, tomato sauce, seaweed and parmesan.

The issue is that MSG is in literally everything, from tomatoes to chicken stock/bouillon (especially in transformed, industrial shit). If you have a specific allergy regarding this crap, you usually are pretty careful about the shit you eat and you pre-emptively notify your host about your particular issues, just as if you were allergic to nuts.

People telling you they're allergic to MSG usually do not go through this process, and only acknowledge they have it when the host explicitely said that they added that particular additive

I usually use a few dash of maggi sauce in lieu of msg powder (unless the flavor doesn't make sense in a particular dish, in which case i just use plain msg), especially in sauces. This is because I mostly only deglaze with water, since I use a lot of spices, the meat already has a meaty flavor and the stocks usually just overpower the flavors already contained in the dish. a stock tends to round up the flavor. Whereas this way i can still taste the spices and the meat sharply so, while retaining the extra savoriness thanks to MSG. It also gives me a greater degree of control on my additives, be they salt or msg or anything. I hate to cook with pre-spiced, pre-flavored stuff because it's usually made for a mainstream public which means the flavors are unvariably dull.
